title: Juan Pablo Caffa
text:
Juan Pablo Caffa (born 30 September 1984) is an Argentine former <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who played as a <a href="Midfielder%23Winger">left winger</a>.
His nickname was "El violinista del Viaducto" (literally translated as "The <a href="violin">violin</a>ist of the viaduct"), as he played an imaginary <a href="violin">violin</a> during his <a href="goal%20celebration">goal celebration</a>s. His professional career, other than in his own country where he represented <a href="Boca%20Juniors">Boca Juniors</a>, <a href="Ferro%20Carril%20Oeste">Ferro Carril Oeste</a> and <a href="Arsenal%20de%20Sarand%C3%AD">Arsenal de Sarandí</a> (two spells), was spent in Spain, Greece, Uruguay, Ecuador and the United States.
Club career.
Argentina.
Born in <a href="Murphy%2C%20Santa%20Fe">Murphy, Santa Fe</a>, Caffa was part of <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Boca%20Juniors">Club Atlético Boca Juniors</a> youth system, being already with the first team when it won the <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20in%20Argentine%20football">2003 "Apertura"</a>, although he only featured in one <a href="Argentine%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">league</a> match.
In the following years, he played with <a href="Ferro%20Carril%20Oeste">Ferro Carril Oeste</a> and <a href="Arsenal%20de%20Sarand%C3%AD">Arsenal de Sarandí</a>.
Spain.
After a number of strong displays with Arsenal during the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20in%20Argentine%20football">2006 "Apertura" tournament</a>, Caffa earned a <a href="Euro">€</a>2 million transfer to <a href="Real%20Betis">Real Betis</a> in the January 2007 transfer window. He played his first <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> match on 4 February against <a href="Athletic%20Bilbao">Athletic Bilbao</a>, but went scoreless in his six <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20La%20Liga">season</a> appearances, also not finding the net in <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20La%20Liga">his first full campaign</a> although he did not start regularly for the <a href="Andalusia">Andalusia</a>ns.
In <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">2008–09</a>, Caffa played on loan with <a href="Real%20Zaragoza">Real Zaragoza</a>, being an important attacking element as they returned to the first division after just one year out. Again at Betis, he appeared in 32 games – although only ten starts– and scored seven goals, but the club <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">failed to regain top-flight status</a>.
Return to Argentina.
In early December 2010, Caffa bought out the remainder of his contract with Betis and returned to Argentina to his former team Arsenal, agreeing on a three-year contract.
